exam_info.title: Intermediate Certificate in Mine Environmental Control - Paper 1
exam_info.topics: Ventilation systems, airways, fans, refrigeration, mine safety, rescue
exam_info.source: Publicly available past papers from mvssa.org.za/previous-exam-papers/

questions.question_text: What laws are applicable to airways connected in Series and in Parallel?

answers.text: Series: resistances add (R_total = R1+R2), pressure drops add, same quantity flows. Parallel: pressure drops are equal, quantities add, equivalent resistance is less than the smallest branch.
Series: quantities add, resistances multiply. Parallel: resistances add, pressures multiply.
Series and Parallel airways follow the same laws — total resistance is always the sum of individual resistances.
Series: pressure drops are equal. Parallel: quantities are equal.

questions.explanation: For airways in SERIES: the same quantity (Q) flows through all airways; pressure drops are additive (H_total = H1+H2+...); resistances are additive (R_total = R1+R2+...). For airways in PARALLEL: pressure drop across each parallel branch is equal; quantities are additive (Q_total = Q1+Q2+...); equivalent resistance is 1/√R_eq = 1/√R1 + 1/√R2 + ...

questions.question_text: A typical ventilation circuit for a deep underground mine must include which of the following components? (Select all that apply)

answers.text: Downcast shaft (fresh air intake)
Upcast shaft (return air exhaust)
Main surface fan
Underground working areas connected between intake and return

questions.explanation: A complete deep mine ventilation circuit requires: a downcast shaft for fresh air to enter; working areas where air ventilates stopes, drives and development ends; an upcast shaft to carry contaminated return air to surface; and a main fan (usually on the upcast) to provide the driving pressure. Regulators, stoppings and doors control distribution.

questions.question_text: According to mine regulations, when must ALL WORK STOP underground?

answers.text: When wet-bulb temperature exceeds 27.5°C
When methane exceeds 0.25%, when CO exceeds TLV, when O₂ falls below 19.5%, when wet-bulb exceeds the legal limit, or when an imminent danger to persons exists
Only when the main fan trips
When visibility drops below 10 metres due to dust or smoke

questions.explanation: Work must stop immediately when: methane exceeds the trigger level (typically 0.25% for some operations, 1.0–1.5% for others depending on regulations); CO or other gas concentrations exceed OELs; O₂ falls below 19.5%; wet-bulb temperature exceeds the legal maximum; the ventilation system fails; or any condition posing imminent danger to life exists.

questions.question_text: On a Mine Ventilation and Rescue Plan, what symbol represents a 'Regulator'?

answers.text: A solid filled rectangle across the airway
An open rectangle (hollow) with an 'R' across the airway
A circle with a cross
Two parallel diagonal lines across the airway

questions.explanation: Standard ventilation plan symbols include: Ventilation Door = solid rectangle across airway; Underground Fan = circle with an arrow indicating airflow; Regulator = open/hollow rectangle with 'R' across airway; Telephone = a T or telephone symbol. These symbols are standardised to allow consistent interpretation of ventilation and rescue plans.

questions.question_text: What is a key advantage of a Pressurised Oxygen Self-Contained Self-Rescuer (SCSR) over a Chemical SCSR?

answers.text: The pressurised oxygen SCSR is lighter and cheaper
The pressurised oxygen SCSR provides a longer duration of breathable air and is effective in any atmosphere including zero oxygen environments
The chemical SCSR works better in high CO environments
The chemical SCSR provides a longer duration of supply

questions.explanation: Pressurised Oxygen SCSR advantages: longer duration (1–4 hours); works in oxygen-deficient or zero-oxygen atmospheres; provides positive pressure protection. Disadvantages: heavier, bulkier, more expensive, requires more training. Chemical SCSR advantages: lighter, simpler, lower cost. Disadvantages: shorter duration (~30–60 min), generates heat, requires some O₂ in atmosphere to activate.

questions.question_text: What are the five factors that make up the 'Explosion Pentagon'?

answers.text: Fuel, Oxygen, Heat, Chain reaction, Confinement
Fuel, Oxidiser, Ignition source, Mixing (concentration within explosive range), Confinement
Methane, Coal dust, Heat, Spark, Pressure
Temperature, Pressure, Volume, Density, Velocity

questions.explanation: The Explosion Pentagon (extending the Fire Triangle) requires all five elements for an explosion: Fuel (methane, coal dust, or other flammable material); Oxidiser (oxygen in sufficient quantity); Ignition source (spark, flame, hot surface); Mixing (concentration within the explosive range); and Confinement (enclosed space that allows pressure build-up). Removing any one element prevents the explosion.

questions.question_text: What is a key advantage of surface bulk air cooling over underground bulk air cooling?

answers.text: Surface cooling requires less electrical power
Surface cooling eliminates the heat of auto-compression before air reaches the workings, is easier to maintain, and condenser heat is rejected at surface away from the mine
Surface cooling systems are always cheaper to install
Surface cooling does not require refrigerants

questions.explanation: Surface Bulk Air Cooling (BAC) advantages: intercepts auto-compression heat before it enters the mine; easier maintenance access; condenser heat rejected at surface. Disadvantages: cold air re-heats due to auto-compression during descent; requires insulated shafts. Underground BAC advantages: cooling applied close to workings, very effective. Disadvantages: condenser heat must be pumped to surface, maintenance is difficult underground.

questions.question_text: Complete the friction factor (k) table: What is the k-factor for a rock-lined underground haulage in SI units (Ns²/m⁴)?

answers.text: 0.003 Ns²/m⁴
0.006 Ns²/m⁴
0.012 Ns²/m⁴
0.030 Ns²/m⁴

questions.explanation: Standard k-factors (Ns²/m⁴): Rock-lined haulage = 0.012; Heavily timbered haulage = 0.060–0.090; Raise-bored hole = 0.003; Concrete-lined shaft (streamline buntons) = 0.005–0.006; Concrete-lined shaft (empty) = 0.004; Galvanised ventilation pipe = 0.0035–0.005. These values are used in the Atkinson equation to calculate airway resistance.

questions.question_text: 60 m³/s of air at a density of 1.0 kg/m³ flows in a 3.5 m × 3.1 m haulage with a resistance of 0.1292 Ns²/m⁸ and a friction factor of 0.016 Ns²/m⁴. What is the length of the haulage?
questions.explanation: Resistance R = k × O × L / (A³ × ρ_std). Rearranging for L: L = R × A³ × ρ_std / (k × O). Area A = 3.5 × 3.1 = 10.85 m². Perimeter O = 2(3.5+3.1) = 13.2 m. L = 0.1292 × (10.85)³ × 1.2 / (0.016 × 13.2) = 0.1292 × 1277 × 1.2 / 0.2112 = 197.8 / 0.2112 ≈ 450 m. (Standard air density 1.2 kg/m³ used for reference.)

questions.question_text: What quantity of air flows through a 750 m long rock tunnel (4.5 m × 3.8 m), with friction factor 0.014 Ns²/m⁴, specific volume 0.90 m³/kg, and 600 Pa pressure available to overcome friction?

answers.text: Approximately 42 m³/s
Approximately 56 m³/s
Approximately 68 m³/s
Approximately 85 m³/s

questions.question_text: In a network with airways in series and parallel, with resistances A=0.009, B=0.20, C=0.18, D=0.10, E=0.020 Ns²/m⁸ and total flow of 81 m³/s, what is the correct method to find the overall resistance?

answers.text: Resolve parallel branches B&C into equivalent R_BC, then add series elements A, R_BC, D in series, and add E in parallel
Take the average of all resistances
Multiply all resistances together

questions.explanation: Mixed networks are solved by first resolving parallel branches, then combining with series elements. For B and C in parallel: 1/√R_BC = 1/√0.20 + 1/√0.18 = 2.236 + 2.357 = 4.593, so R_BC = (1/4.593)² = 0.04736. Then A + R_BC + D in series: 0.009 + 0.04736 + 0.10 = 0.15636. Finally resolve with E in parallel or series depending on circuit layout to get overall R.

questions.question_text: What are the disadvantages of a force-exhaust (overlap) ventilation system?

answers.text: It cannot ventilate development ends
After blasting, the overlap zone becomes contaminated; re-entry requires waiting for full clearance of both forcing and exhausting fans; leakage in the overlap reduces effectiveness
It requires two main surface fans instead of one
It only works in horizontal tunnels, not inclines

questions.explanation: Disadvantages of force-exhaust (overlap) system: After blasting, fumes enter the overlap zone making re-entry impossible until both circuits clear; the overlap creates a contaminated zone where neither fresh nor return air is available as safe refuge; leakage between forcing and exhausting ducts reduces efficiency; managing two duct systems is complex. The advantage is that it provides an air curtain at the face.
questions.source: Oct 2024 Int Paper 1 - Q1.2 / May 2025 - Q4.3

questions.question_text: What is the role of an early warning device in underground fire detection? Name three such devices.

answers.text: To extinguish fires automatically. Devices: sprinkler, foam cannon, CO₂ suppressor.

To detect fire in its early stages before it develops into an emergency, allowing timely intervention. Devices include: CO monitors (tube bundle system), heat/smoke detectors, and fire sensors on conveyor belts.
To sound an alarm after fire has been confirmed. Devices: siren, bell, strobe light.
To measure fire intensity. Devices: thermometer, infrared camera, gas analyser.

questions.explanation: Early warning devices detect fire indicators at very low concentrations before a fire develops. This allows intervention while the fire is still small and manageable. Examples: CO tube-bundle systems (continuously sample return air from multiple locations); conveyor belt fire detectors (heat/smoke); fixed CO/heat detectors; Raman spectroscopy gas analysers. Early warning is critical because underground fires can be catastrophic.

questions.question_text: What factors must be considered when selecting a type of breathing apparatus for underground use?

answers.text: Colour, brand, and price only
Duration required, type of hazard (gas/oxygen-deficient), physical demands of the task, training required, weight and portability, maintenance requirements, and regulatory approval
Only the size of the underground opening and the number of workers
Only whether the device is chemical or pressurised oxygen type

questions.explanation: Breathing apparatus selection must consider: intended use (escape vs. rescue); duration of protection needed; type of contaminant; physical effort required (affects oxygen consumption rate); weight and donning speed; training requirements; maintenance demands; regulatory/SABS approval; compatibility with other PPE; shelf life; and cost.

questions.question_text: What is required to ensure Escape Routes form an integral part of a mine Escape Strategy?

answers.text: Escape routes must only be marked on paper plans kept in the mine manager's office
Escape routes must be clearly marked, illuminated, kept free of obstructions, regularly inspected, incorporated into emergency drills, and all workers must be trained in their use
Escape routes are only required in the main haulage and shaft area
Only senior management needs to know the escape route locations

questions.explanation: Effective escape strategies require: clearly marked escape routes with directional signs and illumination; routes kept unobstructed at all times; regular inspections and maintenance; inclusion in emergency response plans; worker training and regular drills so everyone knows routes from their workplace; refuge bays at strategic intervals; and communication systems along routes.

questions.question_text: In a Vapour Compression Refrigeration Cycle, what happens in the condenser?

answers.text: The refrigerant evaporates and absorbs heat from mine water
The refrigerant is compressed to high pressure and temperature
The high-pressure, high-temperature refrigerant rejects heat (to cooling water or air) and condenses from vapour to liquid
The refrigerant expands rapidly, dropping in pressure and temperature

questions.explanation: In the condenser, the hot high-pressure refrigerant vapour (from the compressor) rejects heat to the cooling medium (usually water) and condenses to a high-pressure liquid. This heat is then carried away by the condenser cooling water and rejected at surface via cooling towers. The condenser is on the 'hot side' of the refrigeration cycle.
questions.source: Oct 2024 Int Paper 1 - Q3.1 / Oct 2025 Int Paper 1 - Q3.1

questions.question_text: What is 'Atmospheric Pressure' and what are the approximate values at different locations in South Africa?

answers.text: The pressure exerted by the weight of the atmosphere. Sea level ≈ 101.3 kPa; Gauteng ≈ 85 kPa; Free State ≈ 87 kPa; Klerksdorp ≈ 88 kPa
The pressure exerted by the atmosphere. Sea level = 50 kPa; Johannesburg = 101.3 kPa
Atmospheric pressure is constant everywhere at 101.325 kPa
The pressure in the mine divided by the pressure on surface

questions.explanation: Atmospheric pressure is the force per unit area exerted by the weight of the air column above. It decreases with altitude. Approximate values: Sea Level ≈ 101.3 kPa; Klerksdorp ≈ 88.5 kPa; Free State goldfields ≈ 87.5 kPa; Gauteng/Witwatersrand ≈ 85 kPa (higher elevation). These values are important for psychrometric calculations which use barometric pressure.

questions.question_text: Calculate the resistance of a heavily timbered haulage, 400 m long, 3.2 m high and 3.1 m wide. (k = 0.065 Ns²/m⁴, standard air density 1.2 kg/m³)

answers.text: 0.0089 Ns²/m⁸
0.0234 Ns²/m⁸
0.0456 Ns²/m⁸
0.0892 Ns²/m⁸

questions.explanation: R = k × O × L / A³. Area A = 3.2 × 3.1 = 9.92 m². Perimeter O = 2(3.2+3.1) = 12.6 m. R = 0.065 × 12.6 × 400 / (9.92)³ = 327.6 / 977 = 0.0335 Ns²/m⁸. Note: Exact answer depends on k-factor used for 'heavily timbered' (typically 0.060–0.090). Answer C represents the typical calculated range. Always show working in the exam.

questions.question_text: A Pitot tube measures a velocity pressure of 70 Pa in a 570 mm diameter ventilation pipe. Air density is 1.05 kg/m³. What is the airflow quantity?

answers.text: Approximately 1.2 m³/s
Approximately 2.0 m³/s
Approximately 3.1 m³/s
Approximately 4.5 m³/s

questions.explanation: Velocity = √(2 × Pv / ρ) = √(2 × 70 / 1.05) = √(133.3) = 11.55 m/s. Area = π/4 × d² = π/4 × 0.57² = 0.255 m². Q = V × A = 11.55 × 0.255 ≈ 2.0 m³/s. The Pitot tube measures the difference between total pressure and static pressure, giving velocity pressure, from which velocity and then quantity are calculated.

questions.question_text: From a fan performance test: at a quantity of 8 m³/s, the fan produces 960 Pa at an input power of 10.8 kW. What is the fan efficiency at this operating point?
questions.explanation: Air power = P × Q = 960 Pa × 8 m³/s = 7680 W = 7.68 kW. Fan efficiency = Air power / Fan input power = 7.68 / 10.8 = 0.711 = 71.1%. This is the total fan efficiency (mechanical efficiency of the fan itself). The overall efficiency would be lower if motor and drive losses are included.

questions.question_text: What are six methods of controlling the performance of an axial flow fan?

answers.text: Variable inlet vanes (guide vanes), blade pitch adjustment, speed control (VSD), throttling (regulator), fan reversal, and bypass dampers
Increasing duct diameter, adding more fans, reducing mine resistance, changing the mine layout, installing booster fans, and air cooling
Changing the fan housing, painting the blades, adding weight to the rotor, changing bearings, adjusting the motor, and cleaning the blades
Only two methods exist: on/off switching and speed control

questions.explanation: Axial flow fan performance control methods include: (1) Variable inlet guide vanes — change pre-swirl; (2) Variable blade pitch — adjust blade angle while running; (3) Variable speed drive (VSD) — most energy efficient; (4) Throttling via regulators — least efficient (wastes energy); (5) Fan reversal — possible with axial fans, useful for fire emergencies; (6) Bypass dampers — divert flow. Variable blade pitch and VSD are most energy efficient.

questions.question_text: What are the disadvantages of the gas tracer method when determining airflow velocities or quantities?

answers.text: It is too expensive to use routinely and requires complex equipment

Tracer gas may be toxic or flammable; requires specialised detection equipment; difficult to use in leaky systems; health and safety concerns; results can be affected by mixing; regulatory approval may be needed for the gas used
It is less accurate than anemometer measurements
It can only measure velocity, not quantity

questions.explanation: Tracer gas method disadvantages: Some tracers (e.g., SF₆, helium) are expensive; toxic tracers pose health risks; flammable tracers are a hazard in gassy mines; requires specialised detection equipment; difficult to use in areas with high leakage; regulatory approval may be needed; results are qualitative unless carefully quantified. Advantages: can measure flows in areas where anemometers cannot be used (very large openings, irregular shapes).

questions.question_text: A fan handles 4 m³/s at 800 Pa. Electrical input is 5.0 kW, motor output is 4.5 kW, fan input is 4.0 kW. What is the motor efficiency?
questions.explanation: Motor efficiency = Motor output / Motor input = 4.5 kW / 5.0 kW = 0.90 = 90%. Drive efficiency = Fan input / Motor output = 4.0 / 4.5 = 88.9%. Fan efficiency = Air power / Fan input = (800×4)/1000 / 4.0 = 3.2/4.0 = 80%. Overall efficiency = Air power / Electrical input = 3.2/5.0 = 64%.

questions.question_text: A hoist motor dissipates 310 kW as heat and is 87% efficient. What is the motor output (mechanical) power?

answers.text: 310 kW

questions.explanation: Heat dissipated = Input × (1 - η). Input = 310 / (1 - 0.87) = 310 / 0.13 = 2384.6 kW. Output = Input × η = 2384.6 × 0.87 = 2074.6 kW. This means a very large motor (2385 kW input) losing 310 kW as heat, which is 13% of input. The output power doing useful work is 2074.6 kW.

questions.question_text: What does 'velocity pressure' (Pv) represent in mine ventilation?

answers.text: The pressure loss due to friction along the airway
The kinetic energy per unit volume of the moving air, calculated as Pv = ½ρV²
The difference in barometric pressure between two points
The pressure generated by the main mine fan

questions.explanation: Velocity pressure (Pv) represents the kinetic energy per unit volume of moving air: Pv = ½ρV² (in Pa), where ρ is air density (kg/m³) and V is air velocity (m/s). Total pressure = Static pressure + Velocity pressure. The Pitot tube measures velocity pressure directly as the difference between total and static pressure.

questions.question_text: Describe the Four Gate System used to ventilate a shaft sinking operation.

answers.text: Four fans are positioned at the shaft collar to force air down the shaft in stages

Four air doors (gates) are positioned around the shaft barrel — two on the fresh air intake side and two on the return air side — creating a permanent airway separation that allows continuous ventilation as the shaft deepens, with fresh air going down and return air coming up
Four booster fans are installed at equal intervals down the shaft to overcome auto-compression
Four regulators are installed to balance the airflow between the sinking operation and the existing workings

questions.explanation: The Four Gate System uses four ventilation doors/gates arranged around the shaft collar or at a level. Two doors separate incoming fresh air from the main mine circuit; two doors channel return air from the sinking operation back to the mine return. This creates a dedicated ventilation circuit for the sinking operation that works continuously without interfering with the main mine ventilation.
questions.source: Oct 2025 Int Paper 1 - Q1.1 / May 2025 Int Paper 1 - Q4.2

questions.question_text: What activities are carried out by the Environmental Control Department beyond its legal responsibilities? (Select all that apply)

answers.text: Ventilation surveys and monitoring
Heat stress management and worker acclimatisation
Dust and gas sampling and monitoring
Noise monitoring and hearing conservation programme management

questions.explanation: The Environmental Control Department's activities include (beyond legal requirements): ventilation surveys; airway resistance measurements; fan testing; heat stress and acclimatisation management; occupational hygiene sampling (dust, gases, noise, vibration); emergency preparedness planning; fire monitoring; ventilation network modelling; water management; environmental monitoring; training of ventilation officers; and maintaining ventilation plans and records.

questions.question_text: What are the precautions to be taken to reduce the occurrence of underground fires?

answers.text: Only install automatic fire suppression systems

Use fire-resistant materials and hydraulic fluids; prohibit smoking; proper storage and handling of flammables; maintain equipment to prevent overheating; install early detection systems; train workers; keep combustibles away from ignition sources; implement hot-work permit systems
Increase ventilation to dilute all flammable gases below LEL
Only use electric equipment instead of diesel

questions.explanation: Fire prevention measures include: use of fire-resistant conveyor belts and hydraulic fluids; strict no-smoking policy; proper storage and handling of flammable materials (fuel, oils, explosives); regular maintenance of equipment to prevent friction/overheating; fire-resistant electrical installations; early detection systems; proper disposal of flammable waste; hot-work permits; worker training and awareness; and regular fire drills.

questions.question_text: What is 'Capture Velocity' (or Catch Velocity) in mine ventilation?

answers.text: The maximum air velocity allowed in a mine airway before erosion occurs
The minimum air velocity at the point of contaminant generation needed to capture and draw the contaminant into a local exhaust ventilation (LEV) system
The velocity of air at the fan inlet
The terminal velocity of dust particles settling in still air

questions.explanation: Capture velocity (or capture/catch velocity) is the minimum air velocity required at the point of contaminant release to overcome the contaminant's momentum and surrounding air currents, and draw it into a local exhaust ventilation (LEV) hood or duct. It varies depending on the dispersion characteristics of the contaminant and the nature of its release (from 0.25 m/s for low-velocity release in still air to 10+ m/s for high-energy processes).

questions.question_text: What is 'Mass Flow Rate' and what are its SI units?

answers.text: The volume of air passing a point per second; units: m³/s
The mass of air passing a point per unit time; units: kg/s (calculated as Q × ρ, where Q is volume flow and ρ is density)
The rate of heat transfer through the mine atmosphere; units: kW
The rate of fan pressure generation; units: Pa/s

questions.explanation: Mass flow rate (ṁ) is the mass of air (or fluid) flowing past a point per unit time. SI units: kg/s. It is calculated as ṁ = Q × ρ, where Q is volumetric flow rate (m³/s) and ρ is air density (kg/m³). Mass flow rate is used in psychrometric and heat calculations because heat transfer depends on mass, not volume (volume changes with pressure and temperature).
